title: Will Iran launch a medium,  intermediate, or intercontinental range ballistic missile or a satellite between 29 November 2017 and 29 December 2017?
preds: The probability of Iran launching an ICBM or other missile in  the next 24 hours is low given the climate at this exact moment.

-Without extreme external provocation, Iran has no current need or desire to launch a missile. Additionally, because of the holidays being celebrated (principally in the West, but to some degree globally), a contemporary satellite launch would not garner Iran the same attention if conducted at another time.
Not directly they like to have it look as though others do their dirty work.

Updating based on time left in 2017.   See http://www.iranwatch.org/our-publications/weapon-program-background-report/iran-missile-milestones-1985-2017   to take note how often missile launches occur.
Doubt Iran will do this in the next remaining few days.
There are only four (three really) days left for this to happen. It has not yet, as I understand, so it's unlikely it will in the few days remaining.
Iran hasn’t seemed inclined to “rock the boat” recently, and there is little reason to believe that will change in the next few days.
They have not done so thus far, and do not wish to further complicate their relationship with the United States or other US partners in the region.
4 launches in 51 weeks gives a historical mean of 7.8% chance any given week. Half a week left and that leaves us with ~4%
No need to display their discontent at Trump by launching under their own flag, when they can supply Yeman.
No payoff for it in current climate
Trump and israel will see this doesn't happen.
Tensions too high in the region.
It would risk the nuclear arms deal being decertified which Iran would want to avoid happening.

Why launch one yourself? 
"The Saudi-led coalition battling Yemen's Houthi rebels says it has intercepted a ballistic missile near Riyadh, Saudi-owned Al-Arabiya TV says."
http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-42412729

It is certainly in the news. https://www.reuters.com/article/us-france-germany/france-germany-want-iran-to-reverse-ballistic-missile-program-idUSKBN1DY1MY US talking about Iranian weapons in Yemen https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-iran-arms/in-first-u-s-presents-its-evidence-of-iran-weaponry-from-yemen-idUSKBN1E82J6 perhaps make it a little less likely to need to advertise capabilities.
No risk of further deterioration in  an already bad realtionship
They will not risk sanctions until they can get their nuclear program back to bombs.
Will not do anything until seeing the US Congress decision.

There is a possibility of a launch, however, Iran may opt to avoid increasing visibility of their activities given that the US currently has its focus on North Korea. They stand a greater chance to continue operating in the periphery in order to begin ramping up their missile and nuclear programs now that the US has lapsed in its responsibility to certify the deal.

Iran tests new ballistic missile hours after showing it off at military parade September 24, 2017
Iran test-fires new ballistic missile
https://edition.cnn.com/2017/09/23/middleeast/iran-ballistic-missile-test/index.html Given prior frequency of missile tests, this is fairly obvious. A little bit of a puzzle why consensus is at 0%. The only way to survive against the USA is via deterrence, and missiles and nuclear weapons are the best conceivable tool for the job.

Two such launches have already been conducted this year.
The US administration is not likely to change policy towards Iran in the coming month.
However there is still a general risk that Iranian strategic level counters (such as advances in their missile program) to US policies will be demonstrated in this month.
A very small window for something that doesn’t happen regularly to happen.

While Iran might try to make some sort of "strong" stance vis-a-vis the Trump government, it is not in Iran's interest to risk loosing support for the deal from the rest of the parties involved in the deal (especially in regards to European partners). As such the launch of a ballistic missile at this moment is somewhat unlikely. Yet, consider the Trump administrations stance ( as well as the rest of the political conditions in the region, especially Saudi Arabia) might make some in Tehran think that a show of force (such as that which could be created by launching a satellite) could be seen as beneficial for the regime.
